title: local-authority-launches-pioneering-eco-friendly-car-hire-in-the-borders
story: A PIONEERING new motoring project has hit the road in the Scottish Borders.A fleet of brand-new, low emission Toyota Yaris hybrids have arrived in several Borders towns.And you can drive the eco-friendly vehicles for as little as pound. an hour or pound per day.The scheme is being delivered by Scottish Borders Council in partnership with E-Car Club.Councillor Simon Mountford told us: ldquoWe already have a successful partnership with E-Car Club to use Toyota Hybrids as pool cars for our staff."As a result of this we have seen more shared journeys by employees, a reduction in business mileage claims and lower emissions."This next stage, which allows members of the public to join a car club scheme, is hugely exciting."Vehicles are available to book across the Borders and I believe many of our local residents will take advantage of this when they need access to a car for a few hours or even a full day.The vehicles are specially adapted to include an RFID card access system, meaning the cars can be booked online or through the free E-Car Club mobile app.Bookings can be made for anyof time over one hour, and insurance is even included in the price.Patrick Cresswell, Managing Director at E-Car Club, commented: ldquoWe are delighted to give Borders residents the opportunity to integrate low emission vehicles into their everyday lives through E-Car which offers a self-service, low cost and low emission car club."Itrsquos a flexible solution for drivers who donrsquot want to commit to car ownership but need access to a car from time to time."We hope this scheme will encourage car owners to consider using the service as an alternative to vehicle ownership. And that should result in fewer cars on the road, and ultimately reducing emissions and congestion.The cars are parked in Peebles, Eyemouth, Duns, Kelso, Galashiels, Hawick and Newtown St Boswells, in allocated spaces prepared by Scottish Borders Council.As the vehicles double up as local authority pool cars they are only available in the evenings and overnight between pm and am from Monday to Wednesday.But they are for hire anytime from pm on Thursday through to am on Monday.As the vehicles are hybrid, they come with two power sources - a petrol engine and an electric motor.The majority of Toyota Hybrids are self-charging which means that every moment you are driving, your battery is charging even when slowing down.This is thanks to technology like the regenerative braking system, which recovers energy that would normally be lost and stores it in the battery for later use.And because they are all self-charging hybrids, their batteries never need to be plugged in.E-Car Club is promoting a special introductory offer to coincide with the launch which includes FREE letime membershipplus pound free driving credit.Simply visit: www.ecarclub join and enter code: WELCOMESB to claim this offer.

title: selkirk-primaries-set-for-boundary-change
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council is set to consult on the catchment areas for two Selkirk primary schools.Following a decline in the number of pupils at Yarrow Primary School, council officers are looking at altering the catchment area to include homes that are currently within Philiphaugh Community Schoolrsquos catchment.The plans would mean that pupils from Yarrowford and Broadmeadows, to the west of Selkirk, would attend Yarrow Primary School instead of Philiphaugh School, which is in town.A report, due to go before Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive meeting on Tuesday  April, explains that a consultation will be carried out with parents prior to any boundary changes.The author of the report, interim service director for children and young people Stuart Easingwood, writes: ldquoThe proposed consultation will seek views on whether there is support for the proposal to amend the catchment areas.ldquoIt is not considered that the proposal will have a material impact on Philiphaugh Community School.ldquoThe number of children in the area under consideration area is relatively low and the Philiphaugh roll has been at a consistent level for a number of years.ldquoThere are currently  pupils at the school which equates to occupancy of %. The average occupancy over the last ten years has been  percent.ldquoIf there is a positive response to the proposal, and a formal recommendation is made to councillors to amend the catchment, it is proposed that pupils, from the Yarrowford and Broadmeadows area, currently attending Philiphaugh, can decide which school they would like to attend and council funded transport will be provided.ldquoThis arrangement will also apply to any future siblings.The consultation,approved by councillors on Tuesday, will run throughout May, culminating in two public meetings on Thursday, may , at Yarrow Primary School and Philiphaugh Community Schools, at .pm and .pm respectively.

title: beauty-students-hope-to-nail-a-place-in-national-qualifiers
story: BORDERS College Beauty Therapy students are hoping to make it through to the National Qualiers of the Beauty Therapy World Skills Competition.Students, Connie Lothian, along with model Kayleigh Scott, and Chloe Thomson, along with model Caitlan McGregor, study on the Beauty Therapy Level  course.The students have spent several weeks brushing up their skills and preparing for the competition, which focuses on the hand and face categories.The initial part of the competition started at the end of last month and involved the students submitting a photographic entry for initial assessment.They spent the day preparing their models to a high standard before professional photographer Phil Wilkinson was invited in to photograph the finished results.Phil spent the afternoon setting up ious photo shoots, which highlighted the best of their work, with the final pictures then submitted to the competition for assessment.The work of the students is now in the hands of the judges, and they face an anxious wait to seethey have been invited to the National Qualiers, which will take place this summer.If they qualy they will be invited to participate in the UK National Final at the NEC in November this year, as part of WorldSkills UK LIVE, the UKs largest interactive apprenticeships, skills and careers event.Heather Fisher, Curriculum Learning Manager, commented: ldquoFollowing on from the recent success of the Hairdressing and Fashion Make-up students at the AHT finals in Blackpool, we thought it would be a great idea for the Beauty Therapy students to be entered in to their own competition.ldquoThe students have been working exceptionally hard over the last month or so and their efforts have shown some excellent results.ldquoThe work the students created on the day of the photo shoot was outstanding and the final photographs highlighted this.ldquoWe should know whether we have qualied or not by May  and look forward to hearing from the judges. Fingers crossed we make it!Lecturer Gail Pow added: "This is a great opportunity for the students to showcase their skills.ldquoThe work they have put in to the competition is second to none and we hope they can secure a place in the next stage.ldquoThe photo shoot was a great experience for both students and lecturers and we are very excited to hear the feedback from the judges."

title: hawick-shoppers-supermarket-sweep-bags-500-for-foodbank

Thank you to ALDI for the opportunity!ALDI held the competition to mark the th anniversary of the opening of their first store in Scotland.Janice Cambridge from the Salvation Army Hawick Foodbank, is delighted with the donation.She said: "The ALDI Supermarket Sweep has generated an amazing amount of money for our foodbank."Caroline has even promised to donate some of the food she grabbed on the trolley dash to our charity."On behalf of the Salvation Army Hawick Foodbank, I would like to say thank you to both ALDI and Caroline for making this generous donation possible.This year ALDI is opening eight new stores across Scotland, creating an additional  jobs by the end of .Richard Holloway, Regional Managing Director for Scotland, added: ldquoThe ALDI supermarket sweep is now a firm favourite across the country and this time it was the turn of Caroline from Hawick to take part."During the five-minute sweep at our Commercial Street store, Caroline managed to snap up a whole load of ALDI treats for herself and whatrsquos more, raise an incredible amount for the Salvation Army Foodbank in Hawick.

title: craig-keeps-it-in-the-family-with-standard-bearer-appointment
story: No Standard Bearer in Selkirkrsquos history can possibly have beenbetter prepared than Craig Monks.Not only is the -year-old fencer following in the footsteps of his grandfather, Drysdale, dad, Keith, and older brother, Rory, but his boss, James Cheyne, was also a Royal Burgh Standard Bearer in .Craig, who has been an Attendant four times since , couldnrsquot hide his delight after being carried around the streets of his ancient hometown.He told us: ldquoIrsquove been brought up with the Common Riding since I was a wee boy.ldquoIt wasnrsquot just Selkirk Common Riding, me and my brothers were dragged round every festival every year.ldquoI live in a house where everyone loves the Common Riding and therersquos always plenty of advice on offer.ldquoEven when I go to work Irsquove got James telling me what to expect.ldquoIrsquove waited a long time for this and so far itrsquos been unbelievable ndash nothing has ever compared to that moment the doors opened and I became the Standard Bearer.Hundreds had gathered in the Market Place to witness Standard Bearer elect Monks hoisted shoulder-high emerging from the Town Hall.And standing above on the balcony were parents, Keith and Iona, along with brothers, Rory and Kieran.Despite the threatening grey skies the rain stayed away. Selkirk Silver and Selkirk Flute bands, as always, created the traditional atmosphere that goes hand-in-hand with Appointment Night.And the foot followers were in good voice.Following the tour of the town, Standard Bearer elect Monks was joined by his  Attendants outside the Appointment Night Concert at the Victoria Halls.Adam Nichol, , Liam Cassidy, , Andrew McColm, , and -year-old Conall Fairbairn will have the honour of following Standard Bearer Monks around the Marches in June.Also preparing for June is the recently appointed Provost.Like Standard Bearer elect Monks, Keith Miller has a fine Common Riding pedigree, having been the Weavers Standard Bearer  years ago as well as holding the position of Deacon from  to .And he admits hersquos excited about what lies ahead.Provost Miller said: ldquoI know Craig and he will do a great job as Standard Bearer.ldquoMy own son, Darren, is also the Weavers Standard Bearer this year.ldquoItrsquos going to be a busy and enjoyable year for all of us.ldquoIrsquom honoured to be Provost and itrsquos been so far so good.Selkirk Common Riding takes place on Friday, June .

title: ancrum-set-for-art-bonanza
story: LOOKING for some culture this May Day bank holiday Ancrum has the answer.The village will be welcoming Art@Ancrum for another year, introducing visitors to three full days of local artists and artwork.Visitors can expect a wide iety of professional art and design-led work available to view and purchase.A mix of  established and new artists and makers will participate in the exhibitions and demonstrations over the bank holiday weekend.The event will include paintings, illustrations, ceramics, textiles, wood, sculpture, jewellery and more.Art@Ancrum is currently in its seventh year and the unique event is hoped to repeat their success by attracting visitors from Scotland, the UK, and beyond.Building on the success of the  lsquoCrossing Bordersrsquo Art Trail exhibition, a group of local participants proposed a new initiative, a long weekend of Art@Ancrum.Since then it has turned into an annual event, supported by the people of the village.Ian Oliver, a spokesperson for the event, said: ldquoArt@Ancrum has become an established favourite in the art world calendar.ldquoYou can enjoy a stroll around the covetable village of Ancrum and pop into some of the charming cottages that will be home to the exhibitions. A truly wonderful way to while away a few hours.The artwork can be found in  dferent venues including artists studios, the village hall and church, rustic outbuildings, and even the Bowling Club.Local pub, the Cross Keys, will also be full of art as it will also house a special exhibition called Absent Friends containing work by artists who cannot attend in person, but whose work is respected and admired by the community.To polish it all off, there will be food, Borders brewed beers and spirits and some cracking live outside entertainment, weather permitting.This year the chosen charity is the "My Namersquo Doddie Foundation".To raise money for the cause there will be collecting cans dotted around for contributions. And teas, coffees, cakes and scones will be served in the Village Hall thanks to the Roxburgh Federation of SWI.The art extravaganza will be held from Saturday, May  to Monday, May . Open from am to pm daily.For more information, check out the website www.artatancrum.org.uk

title: government-rules-against-west-lintons-hen-party-mansion
story: A BORDERS businessman has lost his battle to keep renting out his mansion for lsquoluxury hen partiesrsquo following a planning battle with the council.Michael Cameron, of West Linton, has been renting out the -square-foot Greenloaning Mansion, just north of West Linton, as a luxury getaway for groups of  to  guests, complete with cinema room, spa, two outdoor hot tubs, pool table and gym, since .Mr Cameron charges groups up to pound, for a one-week stay, and even offers chauffeur services in and out of Edinburgh in either a black Bentley, a white Maserati or blacked-out Range Rover. However, Mr Cameron had failed to noty Scottish Borders Council planners about the change of use, who found out once concerned neighbours began to complain about noise disturbances by rowdy hen parties.In November , Mr Cameron received an enforcement notice from the council outlining its grievances, which included concerns over noise disturbances, a detrimental impact on residential amenity and a breach of planning protocol.Mr Cameron subsequently appealed to the Scottish Governmentrsquos department for planning and environmental appeals , saying that because the property has been used for this purpose for more than ten years the council could no longer object to the change of use.The appeal statement also outlines the steps Mr Cameron has made in order to mitigate the noise disturbances from his property.This includes removing two hot tubs from the rear of the building, and instead installing a new one in the spa, which has triple-glazing to minimise noise impact.Mr Cameron has also proposed to remove the barbeque facility from the rear decking of the property, in an effort to stop groups of guests congregating outside.Finally, Mr Cameron has proposed employing a night manager to monitor the property and sound levels between pm and am on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays, and to give the four closest neighbours a direct line to the night manager to raise any issues immediately.Despite this, the DPEA has ruled against the West Linton businessman, and has been two months to cease using the property as a party mansion.Chirs Norman, a DPEA reporter appointed by Scottish Ministers, writes in his ruling: ldquoBefore  November  the availability of lsquoGreenloaningrsquo for holiday letting, and its limited use for  weeks, was ordinarily incidental to its main use as a house.ldquoSome two or three years after  November  it ceased to be the appellantrsquos main residence.ldquoFrom  lsquoGreenloaningrsquo was continually promoted and used as self-catering accommodation for short-stay lets.ldquoOn the balance of probability and on the basis of the evidence before me I find that the unauthorised change of use of the house occurred between  November  and  November .ldquoTherefore the council is not time-barred from taking enforcement action and the appellantrsquos appeal fails.ldquoI find that the house is accessed from an unsurfaced road in the north-east part of West Linton and is in an area characterised by large, in the main, detached houses set in substantial garden grounds in a semi-rural part of the village.ldquoIts location some  metres from the A  and the centre of the village means that residents in the area enjoy a very high standard of amenity.ldquoI have studied the representations on the case and note the alleged impact on residential amenity caused by the use of the property for short-stay letting.ldquoI further note that the appellant has taken steps to curtail the effects of the unauthorised use, and in particular noise and alleged anti-social behaviour.ldquoI am also mindful of the support given by persons staying at lsquoGreenloaningrsquo to businesses in the village.ldquoHowever, I conclude that the unauthorised use of lsquoGreenloaningrsquo has an unacceptable impact on the character of the established amenity in this generally quiet part of West Linton.ldquoExternal activity can arise after . hours and a signicant change into the quiet residential area has been introduced.ldquoThe two-month time period for the cessation of the use is reasonable, given the impact of the unauthorised development on the amenity of this part of West Linton.

title: explorers-great-mystery-comes-to-borders-stages
story: A LIGHT-HEARTED romp featuring starvation, scurvy, cannibalism and some jolly tunes comes to the Borders next week.The new play by Peter Arnott for Mull Theatre, Unspotted Snow, is based on the tale of Sir John Franklinrsquos ill-fated expedition to discover the Northwest Passage.In , Franklin and  men sailed off to discover a route from the Atlantic to the Pacic via the north coast of Canada, but were never seen again.A bold and adventurous account of tragedy, mishap, folly, arrogance and madness, it also serves as a cautionary tale of true-blue British heroism ndash and some ruthless news management.After nine years, news of the expedition was at last brought to London by the remarkable Orcadian explorer and physician John Rae, who worked for the Hudsonrsquos Bay Company.The news he brought was both tragic and grizzly. Unfortunately for Rae, it was the wrong story ndash true, but wrong in that it was not the story that Victorian England wanted.Unspotted Snow is a play of two halves: the first set on the barren ice flows of the Arctic and the second in the equally inhospitable environment of Lady Jane Franklinrsquos drawing room.As playwright Arnott explained, unlike Franklin and the majority of th century British explorers, Rae was uninterested in conquest and the imposition of religious, commercial, or imperial norms on the wilderness.ldquoLike John Muir in Calornia, he anticipated a much more lsquomodernrsquo holistic approach to the natural world, not seeing people as being conquerors of empty space but as inhabitants of a planet shared with other forms of le, he said.The story of the expedition has fascinated the general public, scientists and explorers for over  years.From early findings of frozen corpses and a few artefacts to the very recent discoveries of the expeditionrsquos boats, the Erebusand the Terror , successive generations have been enthralled by the ambition and daring-do of the explorers and by their terrying, macabre fate.That fascination, and the split between two realities, is emphasised by the two-part nature of the play.ldquoIn the first half, a kind of horror-comedy, we have an encounter between three of the last survivors of Franklinrsquos expedition and some Inuit ladies to whom they utterly fail to explain themselves, explained Arnott.ldquoAnd then, in a curious echo of that, we have the inhospitable wilderness of Lady Franklinrsquos Drawing Room, where John Rae again finds himself telling a story that his audience simply cannot, or will not, understand.Unspotted Snow will be performed at the MacArts in Galashiels on Thursday, May  and the following evening at the Eastgate Theatre in Peebles.Tickets for the Galashiels performance, priced at pound and pound, are available from the box office at   .And the Eastgate performance tickets, priced at pound, pound and pound for Under s, are available on  , or online at www.eastgateartsBoth performances begin at .pm.

title: nostalgia-and-psycho-teachers-at-the-macarts

title: travelling-borderer-returns-from-charitable-adventure
story: A BORDERS man has spoken of his eye-opening experiences after two years of travelling the world to assist those in need.Dominic Taddei, who grew up in Hawick and spent almost five years serving his country with the Kings Own Scottish Borderers, decided to leave the Borders behind in .He sold off many of his possessions to fund a two-year volunteering mission across Africa and has ed with a renewed sense of perspective.During his travels across Ethiopia, Kenya and Uganda Dominic witnessed violent election riots, contracted Malaria and suffered a iety of broken bones having fallen down a storm drain.Dominic, who is , told the Border : ldquoWe really donrsquot have any idea of how others live on the other side of the world in some of the poorest countries on earth.ldquoI spent most of my time living in slums, which ied from corrugated houses to mud houses with grass thatched roofs.During his time in Africa, Dominic acted as a trustee for Roll Out the Barrel Trust UK, a project that aims to help with water supply issues in some of the worldrsquos poorest countries.Dominic also helped found a charity in Kenya, The Sunflower Community Orphans Support Project.The organization helps feed orphaned children, many of whom are affected by poverty and HIV AIDS, by using the proceeds of a cafeacute selling food to the public.Dominic fully embraced the lestyle of the local community, enduring the same daily struggles faced by the local population.ldquoI experienced what it was like to have electricity and water shortages and to fetch and carry drinking water.ldquoFor the two years I went without washing machines, showers, fridges, cookers, TV or a flushing toilet.His desire to experience the tough reality of le in these societies is perhaps unsurprising given his previous holiday destinations have included North Korea, Chernobyl and the annexed Crimean Peninsula.Despite the dficulties faced by the communities he assisted, Dominic was struck by the gratitude and positivity he encountered. He said: ldquoThe best part was seeing the smiles and laughs of the people I helped.ldquoThey were grateful and happy, and because I lived like the majority of the people in the slum they made feel a part of the community - I really did feel like it was home.This sense of community was demonstrated when a newly born child was named after him, an experience which left Dominic ldquospeechless and overwhelmed.The experiences of his spartan existence during his charitable travels, and the positivity of communities with so few of the things we take for granted, have shaped Dominicrsquos attitude to le since ing to the UK in March.He added: ldquoAfter selling most of my things to help fund this mission I now own very few items and the ones I do own I appreciate more.ldquoI appreciate things like electricity, running water, showers and fridges.ldquoI now live a fairly simple le and, to be honest, I feel happier doing so.

title: shelagh-saddles-up-for-850-miles-humanitarian-charity-cycle
story: A SEMI-RETIRED doctor from the Borders is prescribing some personal pain in a bid to raise much-needed funds for a humanitarian charity that helps survivors of torture.Shelagh King has been delivering babies at Borders General Hospitals maternity ward for decades.And she has also been active member of the Amnesty International inspired Freedom from Torture charity.Later this summer the -year-old from Newstead will team up with a fellow supporter from Edinburgh, Moira Dunworth, to raise vital funds by cycling some  miles around all of the charitys UK centres.Shelagh told us: "We hope to raise awareness about the Freedom from Torture and the people it supports, meet many other supporters, and raise money for the important work."Freedom from Torture provides counselling, medical evidence of torture for legal cases, and general support for people who have suffered torture."Now that I am semi-retired I have the time and when it was mentioned at the AGM that they were looking for people to join in with Moira on part of the fundraising cycle I decided to sign up and give the whole challenge a go."Shelagh and Moira will leave Hastings on Monday, July  and cycle for the next  days zig-zagging across the UK until they reach Edinburgh at the end of the month.Although Shelagh is an enthusiastic member of athletics clubs Gala Harriers and Lauderdale Limpers she admits shes a novice on two wheels.And in preparation for the Cycle Against Torture she is being coached by friend, Tish Mitchell.Shelagh added: "We are working up my distance slowly and have so far managed  miles in one day."I will certainly be well-trained by the time we set off from Hastings."One of the first patients to receive help from Freedom from Torture was Eric Lomax from Berwick Upon Tweed, whose story was told in the film The Railwayman.Eric was tortured as a prisoner of war in Burma.Nowadays people from all over the world who have suffered torture benefit from the charity.Joining Shelagh and Moira for part of their mammoth cycle challenge will be Syrian refugee Violet, who now lives in Glasgow.And they have also won support from world-record cyclist and broadcaster Mark Beaumont.He said: "I am inspired by the efforts of Moira and Shelagh, both retired and taking on an epic cycle ride from Hastings to Edinburgh alongside Violet, a young Syrian refugee."Freedom from Torture is a brilliant grassroots charity providing medical and psychological care for survivors of torture here in the UK and I am sure that this Cycle against Torture will do brilliantly at raising awareness and funds."Chapeau ladies for this adventure of a letime."To support Shelaghs cycle challenge visit https:www.justgiving fundraising shelagh-king

title: council-backs-plans-for-ettrick-4g
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has approved plans to bring G mobile coverage to the Ettrick Valley.Warrington-based WHP Telecoms plans on erecting a  metre-high G tower on Deephope Hill, just off the B between Eskdalemuir and Ettrick.The plans have largely been welcomed by local residents, who cite the current lack of mobile phone signal as a detriment to both the quality of le in the valley and the ability of businesses to thrive.However, they also attracted nine letters of objection, which cited concerns over the height of the mast, the impact on the landscape and the potential detrimental impact on property prices.One supporter, Ogilvie Jackson, of Selkirk, appeared before Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning and building standards committee on Monday to urge councillors to support the plans.He told the committee: ldquoWe have been lobbying very hard to get mobile coverage in the valley.ldquoFor the last three years our neighbours at Ettrick village have enjoyed good coverage due to government funded masts that tower over the settlement.ldquoThe mast before you will give us near perfect G coverage for the Ettrick Valley.ldquoThe proposed site could not be better. In fact compared to some masts in the Borders itrsquos very discreet.ldquoMany motorists have been stranded and unable to secure help because of the lack of phone signal. This mast will make our valley a safer and more self-reliant place to live.ldquoI would say this to the objectors: itrsquos easy to object to a phone mast just because you donrsquot like phone masts. If that happened everywhere there would be no mobile coverage in the country.Councillors sitting on the planning and building standards committee were advised by planning officers that the benefits outweigh the impact of the mastBarry Fotheringham, the councilrsquos principal planning officer, told the committee: ldquoThe proposed mast and associated equipment form part of a national programme to deliver a new mast network and telecommunications coverage in hard to reach areas in Scotland that do not benefit from mobile telephone connectivity.ldquoThe proposed mast will be visible in the landscape but it is considered that the benefits of having a strong telecommunications signal in the Ettrick Valley outweigh the limited and localised landscape and visual impacts.ldquoThe proposed mast will be future-proofed so that it can accommodate other users and G networks. This will avoid the need for a proleration of other masts locally.ldquoThe proposed development complies with the principal policy requirements of the local development plan and is consistent with ensuring that an improved digital infrastructure is available, to ensure people and communities are better connected.While discussing the proposals, councillors were broadly in favour of granting planning permission.East Berwickshire councillor Helen Laing said: ldquoI have no problem with this application whatsoever. Itrsquos time the Ettrick Valley was brought into the st century.ldquoI absolutely think this is the right decision.Kelso and District councillor Simon Mountford also spoke in favour of the proposals: ldquoIrsquom delighted by this. In this time and age it is unreasonable to expect communities to exist without mobile phone coverage.ldquoAny visual impact is completely outweighed by the economic and social benefits of allowing this application to proceed.Councillors voted unanimously to approve the application.

title: historian-believes-time-is-ticking-for-tracing-selkirks-astronomical-clock
story: Former Selkirk councillor and local historian Kenneth Gunn attempts to unwind the mysteries of Selkirks clocks...THERE has been great anger and humour in almost equal measures recently in the Royal and Ancient Burgh of Selkirk about so-called improvements to the Town Hall and Market Place, which together have left Souters bewildered as to why the changes were made and who is responsible for the short-comings in what was supposed to be an upgrade to the towns heritage.The first thing that happened was at the Town Hall, which was the home of Selkirk Town Council and earlier was the Courthouse of the local Sherf, Sir Walter Scott.A huge underestimate in the costs of restoration saw Scottish Borders Council almost pound, short of the cost of repairing the actual steeple of the Grade A Listed Building.The building has been almost totally ignored since  when the Town Council, and all of Scotlandrsquos town councils, were swept away by a non-local authority system.What now has taken the place of local government is Scottish Borders Council whose neglect actually led to the enormous costs of repair.So what did they do and how did the manage to raise the extra capital to finish the works  They applied for further grants and also took an enormous amount of capital out of Selkirkrsquos Common Good Funds for something that these funds were never intended and all to pay for something which the townspeople had no say in and were not responsible for.That was the angry part but to counter that there is also the humour to record. It was decided by those in high office that the gold-plated cockerel weather vane should be re-plated and that the Selkirk Town Clock should actually be removed for repair and cleaning. That clock and its illuminated front face were well maintained over many years by local jewellers and clock repairers and in more recent times has been well maintained by Ritchies in Edinburgh without recourse to actual removal from the building.This time the entire mechanismwas lowered by jib-crane and taken on a lorry down to England for a complete overhaul. That was fine and no-one noticed as the whole building was enveloped in scaffolding and plastic sheeting.However, when it didand was re-installed in its original place all was not what it seemed.In fact it has never kept time since it was put back in the Town Hall. Sometimes it simply doesnrsquot keep time, sometimes it doesnrsquot go at all and, even worse, it goes backwards!What happened to the role of Clerk of Works in all this turmoil and who signed off the work which was then proved to be faulty in the extreme with the steeple now leaking water where it had never leaked before and with huge double front doors that after ldquorestoration couldnrsquot be opened Is Selkirk actually taking a step back in time Are our Councillors backward Who knows, but come the Common Riding morning letrsquos hope Selkirk Silver Band big drummer John Nicol has a watch that keeps good time or neither the First Drum nor the Second Drum will ever take place!But in the middle of all this confusion I have recovered another great mystery, or is it mysteries What happened to the works of Selkirkrsquos mason-astronomer James Scott who was born in Midlem in  and died in November . Who was he and how did he acquire the title mason-astronomer  We have to rely on an interesting little booklet written by Bowmont Weddell, M.A., F.E.I.S and who was headmaster of Selkirk Public School in the s when he wrote and published the pare which was printed by Walter Thomson in High Street.James Scott was born at ldquoThe Burn in Midlem and followed his father and grand-father into the building trade as a stone-mason after school at Midlem.His hobby was the repairer of clocks and from that he became a builder of time-pieces and studied not just the time of day but also the universe and how it worked and related to time and movement.James was totally self-taught but among the books and manuscripts he read was a lecture paper by the City Astronomer of Edinburgh, William Peck. The stone-mason cum clock repairer got even more interested in the stars and planets and their movements to each other and became so knowledgeable that he could predict the phases of the moon and work out on a nightly basis where its place in the heavens would be.That saw him on a journey in which he designed and built, first of all, his ldquoGreat Clock which told the time accurately while at the same time represent the solar system and the relative movements of the stars and planets around the centre-piece, the sun. Included in this masterpiece are the signs of the Zodiac and through its  spaces this Great Clock tells the time, the placings of the planets and a pointer also displays the date and the year.He developed several clocks, long before the advent of digitisation and modern technology. Some of his works were famous and his Astronomical Clock formed a centre-piece of The Scottish Natural Exhibition in Edinburgh in .The ldquoGreat Clock and his elaborate but extremely accurate ldquoJupiter Clock which spelled out the movement of Jupiter and the rest of the planets in relation to the Sun and Earth, were kept locally and by the date that the Rector of Knowepark Public School, Mr Weddell, wrote his paper in  these valuable inventions were part of the fabric of Selkirk Town Hall, in custody of the people of Selkirk as a tribute and a memorial to a one-time stone mason and self-taught astronomer and clock maker, James Scott.The question is ldquowhere are they now They are obviously parts of Selkirkrsquos heritage and Selkirkrsquos past but also a glowing tribute to what can and should be done even today by people with the right attitude to their own environment.If a tin shed half way down The Green, built as a garage, can in any way be classed as Common Good Property and of any value to the burgh, then all efforts should be involved in finding out where these inventions of James Scott, the Selkirk Mason-Architect are now.These clocks are certainly worthy of the title Common Good property.

title: expect-cues-as-sporting-greats-set-for-book-festival
story: SNOOKER legend Stephen Hendry canrsquot wait for this yearrsquos Borders Book Festival.The seven-time world champion leads a pack of sporting heroes appearing at the Melrose event next month.And he will be bringing the action from many World Championships to le as he discusses his book, Me and the Table.Hendry told us: ldquoI am really looking forward to come down to the Borders.ldquoIrsquove visited two or three times over the years to play snooker, but it has been so long since I was last there.ldquoThe book festival should be a really fun event. There are some big sporting names appearing like David Coulthard, so I am really looking forward to it.Hendryrsquos fascinating autobiography reveals the man behind the legend.lsquoMe and the Tablersquo charts a journey from an upbringing in Edinburgh to a purple patch from March  to January  when he won five titles and was unbeaten in  consecutive matches ndash a feat yet to be repeated.At just , Hendry became the youngest Scottish amateur snooker champion and just a few years later was competing with greats of the game such as Alex Higgins and Jimmy White.In , he retired after losing in the quarter-finals of the World Championship.He is now currently working with the BBC team at the Crucible in Sheffield, commentating on the Betfred World Championship.Hendry added: ldquoI suppose I have always wanted to write a book and after I retired in  I just felt like that was the right time to start.ldquoI really enjoy doing the world championships on TV ndash it is the pinnacle of our sport.ldquoIt is a high pressure event. I like doing the commentary, but I would rather be playing. I think the commentary is the next best thing.Stephen Hendry will appear on the Thursday evening in the McInroy  Wood Marquee at .pm.Tickets are priced at pound and pound.From the peace and quiet of the Crucible, sports fans will be taken to one of the noisiest arenas with former Formula One star David Coulthard.The -year-old Scot, who was runner-up in the  Championship, will discuss his new book, The Winning Formula, in the Douglas Home Marquee on Friday evening.Coulthard raced to  victories from the starting grid of  Grand Prix during a glittering career.And since hanging up his racing gloves in  hersquos become a regular on television screens as commentator and analyst.In The Winning Formula, David opens the doors to the secretive world of F. Not quite so secret is Bob Championrsquos greatest achievement.After battling back from testicular cancer, and while still receiving treatment, he won the  Grand National with Aldaniti. His story was turned into the box office smash, Champions, and earned John Hurt several awards for playing the jockey.Bob will be in discussion with fellow horseracing legend Richard Pitman on Friday afternoon at .pm in the Douglas Home Marquee. He will discuss his amazing autobiography Irsquom Champion, Call Me Bob, which charts his early le, his path to becoming a professional jump jockey and how it felt being at the top of his game only to have it come crashing down with a le-threatening diagnosis.Richard Pitman willto the Book Festival winnerrsquos enclosure on the Saturday for his own show in the Buccleuch Marquee at .pm.The -year-old rode  winners in his career and  losers - including Crisp in the  Grand National where he was pipped to the post by Red Rum.After jockeying for  years he joined the BBC where he spent  years as an interviewer and presenter. He has also written a dozen books, many of them thrillers set in the world of horse racing.Also saddling up on Saturday is the only women winner of The Mongol Derby. Lara Prior-Palmer rode  dferent horses across the plains and deserts of Mongolia to win the epic , kilometres race in  - at the age of only .Driven by her own restlessness, stubbornness, and a lelong love of horses, she raced for seven days through extreme heat and terrying storms, catching a few hours of sleep where she could at the homes of nomadic families. Battling bouts of illness and dehydration, exhaustion and bruising falls, she found she had nothing to lose and tore through the field with her motley crew of horses.,params: .pushIn one of the Derbyrsquos most unexpected results, she became the youngest-ever champion and the first woman to win the race. Told with terric suspense and style, Rough Magic is her extraordinary story. Lara will be in the McInroy  Wood Marquee at .pm.Arguably Gregor Townsendrsquos greatest moments in rugby came locked in a Twickenham changing room for quarter of an hour.Despite a glittering playing career, which saw him win  caps and took him to Northampton Saints, Brive, Castres, Montpellier and the Border Reivers, it is perhaps the recent Six Nations clash with England that he will be best-remembered.With England running riot and leading - after half an hour, coach Townsend masterminded rugbyrsquos greatest ever fightback to earn a - draw.He will discuss Scotlandrsquos six tries on that memorable afternoon as well reflecting on a playing career that began at Netherdale in .Gregor will be in the McInroy  Wood Marquee at .pm on the Friday evening.Although best known for his voice these days, former international Scotland player Ian Robertson will also be talking rugby on Saturday afternoon. Having just retired after  years of commentating for the BBC he will discuss his biography, Rugby: Talking a Good Game, at the McInroy  Wood Marquee on Saturday at .pm.Tickets for all of this yearrsquos sporting greats at the Baillie Gford Borders Book Festival are available from www.bordersbookfestival.org or call the Box Office on   .

title: gala-tech-firm-provides-happy-ever-after-twist-for-book-festival
story: A GALASHIELS tech firm has brought a happy ending to an unfolding story at the Borders Book Festival.Esme Biggar had secured an internship at the popular summer festival in Melrose.But the plot thickened when bosses at Harmony House didnt have enough spare equipment to allow the online whizz from Kelso to help deliver the social media strategy.And it was only after they turned to GB Technologies for help that everyone lived happily ever after.The independent communications provider was able to provide a loan of a Samsung tablet for the duration of Esmes internship.Mark Moncrieff, MD at GB Technologies, said: ldquoItrsquos great to see local youngsters being given meaningful work experience and as a long-term supporter of the Borders Book Festival, we were only too happy to lend Esme the tools needed to carry out her job effectively.As well as the social media, Esme will be assisting with a range of key tasks including programming, media launches and co-ordinating  events over the four-day festival.She told us: ldquoIrsquoll certainly be busy, but Irsquom looking forward to making a signicant dference."The Borders Book Festival is now one of the largest literary events in the country, so to gain transferable skills here, through a proper paid internship, will provide a noteworthy addition to my CV.Now in its th year, The Baillie Gford Borders Book Festival is once again bringing renowned authors, sports stars, politicians, raconteurs and TV personalities to the grounds of Harmony House Melrose from Thursday, June  to Sunday, June .Further details and information and tickets are available online at www.bordersbookfestival.org

title: payout-for-borders-bairns-under-best-start-package
story: EXPECTANT parents in the Borders have received a total pound, under a new Scottish Government initiative.applications for the Pregnancy and Baby Payment were authorised in the Borders between December ,  and February , .This payment is part of the Scottish Governmentrsquos new Best Start Grant package, with payments for low income families provided at key stages of a childrsquos development.Under the Pregnancy and Baby payment pound is provided for a first child and pound for any siblings thereafter.A total of , families across Scotland received a Scottish Government Best Start Grant Pregnancy and Baby Payment during the first three months of the schemersquos rollout.Shirley-Anne Somerville, Cabinet Secretary for Social Security, said: ldquoI am committed to making sure that every child gets the support they need to have the best start in le.ldquoThe huge take-up of this new benefit in its first three months highlights just what can be achieved when you design a service with the people who will actually use it.ldquoIn doing so, we have simplied the application process and offered multiple ways to apply.ldquoWe have found out where we need to promote the payment and who we need to work with ndash including health and childcare professionals - to make sure that people know that they are entitled.ldquoWe want to increase financial support to families, bringing equality to children across Scotland by giving them help towards a fairer start.David Wallace, Social Security Scotland Chief Executive, said: ldquoPregnancy and Baby Payment is the first payment that we launched that required people to apply.ldquoI am delighted with the take up of this so far and to see people applying from all over the country.ldquoWe are not complacent though and we will continue to promote these benefits through communications, marketing and the local face to face service that we are starting to set up to make sure that everyone who is entitled to this support knows about it and applies.ldquoThe Scottish Government sees social security as peoplersquos human right and it is part of our responsibility to deliver a service that enables people to access and exercise this right.

title: no-deal-brexit-ferry-contracts-to-be-scrapped
story: Transport Secretary Chris Grayling is cancelling a set of contracts to provide ferry services after a no-deal Brexit, at a cost estimated at around pound million.Mr Grayling awarded contracts worth a total of more than pound million last December to three firms ndash Brittany Ferries, DFDS and Seaborne Freight ndash to run extra services from ports including Plymouth, Poole and Portsmouth to ease expected pressure on the Dover-Calais route.After the expected March  date of EU withdrawal was delayed, first to April  and now October , sailings went ahead even though the feared disruption to essential supplies like food and medicines did not materialise.--vw,vw,px, px"Transport Secretary Chris Grayling took the decision to scrap the contracts --The National Audit Office estimated in February that the maximum cost of compensation to ferry operatorscontracts were terminated early would be pound. million, but a Whitehall source said the actual figure was expected to be around % lower.Seabornersquos contract to provide sailings from Ramsgate was scrapped in February after an Irish company backing the deal pulled out.The DFT paid pound million to Channel Tunnel operator Eurotunnel in an out-of-court settlement of a claim that the company was unfairly overlooked for the work.Now Mr Graylingrsquos department is being sued by PO Ferries over its complaint that the payment to Eurotunnel put it at a competitive disadvantage.The announcement that the remaining contracts are now to be torn up is likely to fuel speculation that the Government no longer believes a no-deal Brexit might happen.But a Downing Street spokesman said: ldquoDepartments will continue to work with ministers and permanent secretaries to take whatever decisions are required to make sure we are prepared in the event of a no-deal scenario.Shadow transport secretary Andy McDonaldsaid Mr Graylingrsquos handling of the ferry contracts provides ldquoa case study in ministerial incompetence.ldquoThe Transport Secretaryrsquos approach to procurement and planning has cost taxpayers tens,not hundreds, of millions of pounds, said Mr McDonald.ldquoHis career as a minister has left a trail of scorched earth and billions of pounds of public money wasted.This country cannot afford Chris Grayling.A Number  source said that Theresa May continues to have ldquofull confidence in Mr Grayling.had listened to the maritime unions none of this would have happened" data-source"Mick Cash, RMT union"Britanny Ferries has been operating  additional cross-Channel sailings a week since March  under the contract, despite Brexit not going ahead as expected on that date.Some , passengers had their travel disrupted by new schedules introduced in March to accommodate the DFT contract, which are due to remain in place for six months.The company has taken on  extra port staff in the UK and France and has spent large sums on fuel for the , additional nautical miles sailed each week.Mick Cash, general secretary of the Rail, Maritime and Transport union, said:ldquoThe Brexit ferry chaos on Chris Graylingrsquos watch has lrmmoved from farce to national scandal with the taxpayer picking up the bill.ldquoIf he had listened to the maritime unions none of this would have happened. Grayling has reduced the shipping industry in this island nation to a global laughing stock.Manuel Cortes, leader of the Transport Salaried Staffs Association, said: ldquoThe public will rightly be furious but they wonrsquot be surprised.ldquoChris lsquoFailingrsquo Graylingrsquos utter incompetence has all too often seen millions of pounds from the public purse blown time and again.ldquoGrayling really is the helmsman of this Tory ship of Brexit farce which is fast sinking below the electoral waterline. However, a Department for Transport spokeswoman defended the termination, saying it would cost the public purse less than keeping the contracts.She said: ldquoThe Governmentrsquos freight capacity contracts were a vital part of contingency measures, ensuring goods like medicines could enter the UK in the case of disruption during a no deal Brexit.ldquoFollowing the extension, the Government is reviewing all preparedness plans. The Governmentrsquos freight capacity contracts for the summer period are no longer needed and have therefore been terminated.ldquoThe Government has taken this decision now as it represents the best value for money for taxpayers.ldquoThe termination of these contracts has resulted in less cost to the taxpayer than the termination costs reported by the NAO in their own analysis of the freight capacity contracts..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: No-deal Brexit ferry contracts to be scrapped

title: japans-new-emperor-pledges-to-work-for-peace-as-he-takes-the-reins
story: Emperor Naruhito inherited the sacred sword and jewel that signalled his succession and pledged in his first public address to follow his fatherrsquos example by devoting himself to peace and sharing the peoplersquos joys and sorrows.Naruhito, the first modern emperor to have studied abroad and the first born after Japanrsquos defeat in the Second World War, formally acceded to the Chrysanthemum Throne at midnight after his father Akihito abdicated on Tuesday.----ldquoWhen I think about the important responsibility I have assumed, I am filled with a sense of solemnity, Naruhito said in his address.While noting his fatherrsquos devotion to praying for peace, Naruhito said he will ldquoreflect deeply on the path trodden by Akihito and past emperors. He promised to abide by the constitution that stripped emperors of political power, and to fulfil his responsibility as a national symbol while ldquoalways turning my thoughts to the people and standing with them.ldquoI sincerely pray for the happiness of the people and the further development of the nation as well as the peace of the world, he said.--vw,vw,px, px"People gather in the compound near Imperial Palace in Tokyo --Naruhito is considered a new breed of royal, his outlook forged by the tradition-defying choices of his parents. Emperor Emeritus Akihito devoted his three-decade career to making amends for a war fought in his fatherrsquos name while bringing the aloof monarchy closer to the people.Naruhitorsquos mother, Michiko, was born a commoner and was Catholic educated. Together, they reached out to the people, especially those who faced disability, discrimination and natural disasters.Naruhito was presented with the imperial sword and jewel, each in a box and wrapped in cloth, at a morning ceremony that marked his first official duty.His we and daughter, Empress Masako and -year-old Princess Aiko, were barred from the ceremony, which only adult male royals, his brother, now Crown Prince Fumihito, and his uncle Prince Hitachi, were allowed to witness. Their guests included a female Cabinet minister, however, as the Imperial House Law has no provision on the gender of commoners in attendance.--vw,vw,px, px"Japanrsquos new Emperor Naruhito with Empress Masako --The banning of female royals at the ceremony underscored the uncertain future of a paternalistic imperial family that now has just two heirs.Nevertheless, Japan festively celebrated an imperial succession prompted by retirement rather than death. Many people stood outside the palace Tuesday to reminisce about Akihitorsquos era others joined midnight events when the transition occurred, and more came to celebrate the beginning of Naruhitorsquos reign.Dozens of couples lined up at government offices to submit marriage documents to mark the first day of Naruhitorsquos era, known as Reiwa, or ldquobeautul harmony.Today marks the beginning of the Japans new era, Reiwa   beautul harmony. People are celebrating the Accession to the Throne and, on May, the General Public will visit the Imperial Palace for celebration: https:t.co xnHDRZbIgpic vPYiQUqmdash japanMay , Natsumi Nishimura, a -year-old saleswoman, and Keigo Mori, a -year-old government worker, were at a Tokyo office on Wednesday, saying they decided to tie the knot at the start of a new era to mark their new le together.ldquoOpportunities like this donrsquot come by often so we thought it would be a day we wonrsquot forget, Ms Nishimura said.Japanrsquos prime minister Shinzo Abe congratulated Naruhito on his ascension, pledging to create a ldquobright future during the new era that is peaceful and full of hope.Naruhito also received congratulations from abroad. --vw,vw,px, px"Cars with Japanese flags pass on the double bridge to enter the Imperial Palace --President Donald Trumprsquos message said America and Japan will renew the bonds of friendship in the new era.Chinese President Xi Jinping was quoted by state media as saying China and Japan should work together to promote peace and development and bilateral ties.From a car window on his way to and from the palace, Naruhito smiled and waved at people cheering on the sidewalk. He and his family will continue living at his Togu Palace until they switch places with his parents after refurbishments.Naruhito, , is the nationrsquos th emperor, according to a palace count that historians say likely included mythical figures until around the th century.The emperor under Japanrsquos Constitution is a symbol without political power. Wartime militarist governments worshipped the emperor as a living god until Naruhitorsquos grandfather renounced that status after the countryrsquos  war defeat.Akihito during his three-decade reign embraced an identity as peacemaker and often made reconciliatory missions and carefully scripted expressions of regret on the war. His immersion in that role leaves Naruhito largely free of the burden of the wartime legacy, allowing him to carve his own path.Palace watchers say he might focus on global issues, including disaster prevention, water conservation and climate change, which could appeal to younger Japanese, while also emulating his fatherrsquos focus on peace.That is what many Japanese hope Naruhito will pursue.ldquoI hope the new emperor will be like the Heisei emperor , who cherishes peace, said Takayori Kobayakawa, a -year-old retired person from Shizuoka, central Japan. --vw,vw,px, px"The motorcade of Japanrsquos new Emperor Naruhito, second from right, leaves the Imperial Palace --ldquoI have high hopes for him.Naruhito also faces uncertainties in the imperial household. Crown Prince Fumihito, , and Fumihitorsquos -year-old son, Prince Hisahito, can currently succeed him. The Imperial House Law confines the succession to male heirs, leaving Naruhitorsquos daughter out of the running.Naruhitorsquos we, Empress Masako, is a Hard-educated former diplomat who may prove an adept partner in his overseas travels and activities. But much will depend on her health, since she has been recovering from what the palace describes as stress-induced depression for about  years. He recently said he hopes Masako might slowly expand her role.Masako has largely limited her public appearances since late , after giving birth to their daughter and facing pressure to produce a son. Naruhito criticised palace officials in , though subtly, for denying Masakorsquos personality and career and pushing her into a corner..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Japan us new Emperor pledges to work for peace as he takes the reins

title: glasgow-city-council-leader-reported-to-watchdog-over-smear-claims
story: The leader of Glasgow City Council has been reported to the Standards Commissioner over an allegation she attempted to ldquosmear a fellow councillor.Frank McAveety, the head of the local authorityrsquos Labour group, has lodged a complaint against the SNPrsquos Susan Aitken with the Commissioner for Ethical Standards, claiming she has broken the councillorsrsquo code of conduct.The complaint relates to a report in The Sun newspaper that Ms Aitken posted a picture of Mr McAveety to a private Facebook group for SNP councillors.It included the comment: ldquoIf anyone feels like getting these nice photos of Frank McAveety enjoying hospitality in the Rangers directorsrsquo box out therehellipIt would appear that in July , at the height of the Fanzone controversy, the SNP leader of Glasgow CC sought to belittle her predecessorfor attending a Rangers game at Ibrox. Can @SusaninLangsideconfirm  pic CBcaApcxmdash Adam Tomkins MSPApril , Mr McAveety claims this was an attempt to ldquostir up a sectarian ide but an SNP spokesman told The Sun the post was a ldquojoke.Former Glasgow City Council leader Mr McAveetyrsquos letter states: ldquoIn context, these comments came amid outrage over a decision to withdraw support for a fan zone at Ibrox Football Stadium, leading to claims of political interference in a quasi-judicial decision.It continues: ldquoThe comments, as reported with the images, indicate that the leader of the council wished members of her group to circulate this image, in an apparent attempt to stir up a sectarian ide on this issuehellip.ldquoThese comments and this coordination fall very signicantly short of the behaviour that should be expected of anyone in public le.He claims they breach two sections of the code of conduct relating to respecting colleagues and treating them with courtesy, including on social media.Mr McAveety said: ldquoIn response to legitimate criticism, Susan Aitken has sought to stir up a sectarian ide that our city is trying to consign to the past.ldquoThat is flat-out unacceptable. The leader of the council should reflect on her behaviour and whether this is the standard that Glaswegians expect.ldquoI have asked the Standards Commissioner to investigate this behaviour because I do not believe that it is fitting for behaviour for an elected member.A spokesman for the SNPrsquos Glasgow group said: ldquoEveryone understood Susanrsquos post was a joke, as evidenced by the fact nobody did anything with it..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Glasgow City Council leader reported to watchdog over  usmear u claims

story: Kintyre Wheelers Cycling Club#sEnd of the Worldevent, on the weekend of May  and , had attracted some leading Scottish cyclists but across all events, on both days, there were less than two dozen entries.Entry was through the British Cycling website and EOTW was strongly promoted, by its founder, KWCC secretary Robbie Semple, at the recent Scottish Cycling Running and Outdoor Pursuits Show in Glasgow.With one Monday left to go on entries, at the KWCC committee meeting, in Campbeltown last Wednesday, it was decided to change the event from two days to Sunday only.Any entrants have been fully refunded through British Cycling.It will also be classed as a closed event, confined to KWCC members only.The confined status would mean that anyone from outwith Kintyre could still take part by paying the £ to join KWCC, which is a big discount on the EOTW entry fee.The format has not been confirmed but KWCC#s provisional plan includes a  mile time trial and a MACC Runway Rush, which is a sprint race, recently pioneered at the opening weekend of the season.The event may close with an Australian Pursuit Race ,members have any cycling left in their legs.An APR is a handicap race with the slowest away first over a shorter distance than the planned six hour endurance event.A KWCC spokesperson said: #Hopefully In the future we can look at organising something bigger.#It simply wasn’t going to be viable. The largest entry we had was  for the Saturday  mile time trial and only four competitors were from outwith the area.#However the closed to club event will be free to club members and anyone who joins will have membership till June .#There will be a practice weekend at MACC on Easter Sunday.#Mr Semple re-founded KWCC nearly two years ago. title: letter remote fuel pump prices unfair
story: Rural communities across Scotland and particularly on the Islands are being forced to pay substantially more for vehicle fuel than urban areas.This means deep unfairness for households already facing budget pressures.Residents of the Kintyre and Islands ward rely on their cars to get to and from work as well as visiting family and friends, due to limited public transport links.Pump prices are being inflated in rural areas, as prices are reduced in cities because of competition.On top of getting hammered at the petrol pump  per cent of those living in rural parts of Scotland are likely to be in fuel poverty, compared to  per centin urban areas.Energy prices tend to be higher and incomes tend to be lower in rural areas.Many households rely on fuels like heating oil, electricity, LPG and solid fuel. These markets can be limited, restricting consumer choice and increasing costs.About . per cent of rural households rely on heating oil. Heating oil prices can be volatile, and collective purchasing clubs, which can reduce costs, are uncommon in many parts of rural Scotland.High pump prices and disproportionate levels of fuel poverty are yet more examples of how we in rural Scotland are getting a raw deal.I would implore central governments of all political stripes to recty this imbalance.I will continue to give a voice to the often ignored everyday rural residents.Councillor Alastair Redman,Kintyre and Islands ward.

story: At Campbeltown Bowling Club on Saturday afternoon, president Bobby Dalziel welcomed a good crowd of players who were willing to endure the cold conditions before his we Lorraine sent the first jack straight down the Stronvaar green.She was presented with a bouquet of flowers by vice president David Brown#s two-year-old daughter, Olivia.Across town at Argyll Bowling Club, president Kenny Kerr welcomed members and wished them success for the new season, after which there was a minute#s silence in memory of those members no longer with us.The president#s we, Alison Kerr, rolled the first jack of the season and was presented with flowers by her granddaughter, Charlotte.Players enjoyed the first game of the new season, with the blustery conditions providing an added challenge.The green played well thanks to the hard work of greenkeeper Bobby Mathieson.The presidents were the winners by a narrow margin over the vice presidents. The game was followed by afternoon tea in the clubhouse.

title: letter machrihanish golf clubhouse
story: In one word Machrihanish Golf Course#s clubhouse should be #traditional# in keeping with the golf course and Machrihanish village.The proposal presented by the current committee falls short.The roof line and pitch are the angle of a Chinese pagoda. Instead of a steep Victorian pitch, the proposed roof design looks like a brim hat with the sides down.The design would look good in Hong Kong or the desert of Arizona—not in Machrihanish sited between a row of sandstone manses and the Ugadale Hotel.On the other hand, the existing pro shop is a perfect example of taste in design.The new clubhouse could copy it using reasonable construction costs, for instance two inch by six inch framing faced with a thin stone veneer similar to the cottages at the Ugadale.That is what visitors and guests want to see, a clubhouse in keeping with #Old Tom Morris#.In the name of good design, change it while you still can.Jim Gubler,Las Vegas.

story: The youngsters join a team of - to -year-olds in an initiative designed to strengthen ties between police and young people, teaching recruits about the duties of officers and encouraging good citizenship.Addressing the audience at the youngsters# passing out parade, PC Karen Cairns, the group#s coordinator, spoke about their dedication, commitment and enthusiasm.The Campbeltown branch was the first in Argyll and Bute and the young volunteers signing up, despite schooling and other distractions, is a tribute to their diligence.People often say there is not enough for youngsters to do in small, rural communities like Kintyre, but here it is the opposite.There are so many activities on offer, from sports clubs to music groups, that young people often have to sacrice some for the others.Our young people have so many opportunities.

title: letter council chiefs remuneration package
story: Last week we read of Argyll and Bute Council increasing the fee for shellfish export licenses to a level which threatens to put some exporters out of business. And this at a time when the UK may well have a particular need for all its exports and entrepreneurs to save us from the direst consequences of Brexit.A few weeks ago we read of how the Minard War Memorial has missed out on essential maintenance funding from a nationwide scheme because Argyll and Bute Council neither made the required application within the stipulated period nor took responsibility for its failure.This week we read that the Argyll and Bute Council#s chief executive received an annual remuneration package of around £,. This must seem to most to be an extremely impressive and generous reward for whatever service that particular gentleman has rendered us.Now, it is a long-accepted ethical principle that in the realm of public service a high level of reward must only follow a high level of service.However, it is not at all clear to me # or I would suggest  per cent of the public # exactly how the chief executive has rendered such a level of service as merits such a high level of reward.Putting it into context: Why was so much public money used to reward the chief executive when it could have been put to such uses as properly repairing Minard War Memorial and easing the financial burden on our entrepreneurs I think thatthe chief executive is to retain any credibility, he has face the public in open forum and answer this question.I really hope that he has the courage to meet that challenge.Arthur McFarlane,

title: thought for the week april 19 2019
story: At the close a two-day retreat in the Vatican for the African leaders, the pope asked South Sudan’s president and opposition leader to proceed with the peace agreement despite growing dficulties. Then he got down on his knees and kissed the leaders’ feet one by one.#I express my heartfelt hope that hostilities will finally cease, that the armistice will be respected, that political and ethnic isions will be surmounted, and that there will be a lasting peace for the common good of all those citizens who dream of beginning to build the nation,# the pope said of South Sudan in his closing statement.People were moved to tears as the elderly pope struggled to get down on his knees to kiss the feet of two rival leaders.He did it to bring peace.During the last week of Jesus# le, he too got down on his knees and he washed the feet of his disciples.Jesus adopted the role of servant to do this menial task of washing feet, which would be less than fragrant having shared the same streets with camels and donkeys who were not exactly house-trained.Jesus also wished to bring peace, to show that we are all equal in the eyes of God.Today we stand silent as we think of Jesus dying to show how much God loved us.But on Sunday morning, as we see once again those footprints in the dew, we rejoice that our Lord is risen – to show how much God loves us.

title: lensman focuses on lyrical landscapes in campbeltown talk
story: Dougie Cunningham spoke to Campbeltown and Carradale#s camera clubs, as well as invited guests, about his recently published guidebook, Photographing Scotland, at the Ardshiel Hotel#s Arran lounge recently.Dougie entertained a capacity crowd for nearly two hours with the tale of producing his -page book, which is illustrated with  photographs.Dougie said: #My contract with the publisher was for two years from start to finish but they were understanding and it spread to four years.#It involved travelling thousands of miles in two motorhomes and umpteen ferries.#Although the initial contract took four years to fulfil, it was the impetus Mr Cunningham needed to start travelling round the nation#s best landscape locations.He said: #I sold my car and bought a VW T builders# van and spent another £ making it roadworthy. As it was blue my young niece named it Sully from Monsters Inc.#The van became his base for the multiple trips but proved quite unreliable with many calls to the RAC. Mr Cunningham also found Scotland is a vast country.#Scotland is not small as everyone says,# said Mr Cunningham, #I remember the words on the floor of Central Station # #Scotland is the Best Small Country in the World,# # it is not when you are in a campervan stuck behind a car towing a caravan heading to the far north.#The van broke down on Barra and the RAC rules are that it has to be towed by an authorised RAC garage.#I called up and the operator said go back and wait in your van and we will have someone out to you in a few hours.#I was quite sceptical but after a couple of hours a white  van turned up and one of the men who emerged askedI had tried turning the key.#It dawned on me that they were not mechanics and the other said they had been sent by an RAC garage in South Uist with instructions to push me onto the ferry.#Just down the hill, towards Uig on Skye, Sully#s head gasket went and once again I ed to Glasgow with the RAC and the van in bits.#I had seen so many RAC vehicles the next van I bought was bright orange and my niece named it Nemo.##Perhaps one of the most beautul places I photographed was Islay. So many distilleries which it would be rude to drive past.#Mr Cunningham added: #When I have an opening night at an exhibition it is a great way of spending £ on wine for a bunch of people you are never going to meet again.#The highlight of Scottish landscape photographer Dougie Cunningham#s visit to Kintyre was being snapped with Carradale#s most famous resident, Neenie MacDougall. Rachel Grant on the right has been accompanying Mr MacDougall to Carradale Camera Club for  years. _cphotographer_Neenie_MacDOugall

title: alan reid to stand for libdems
story: Mr Reid served as the MP for Argyll and Bute from  until  and is currently a councillor for the Cowal ward.#The Scottish Liberal Democrats is the only party committed to keeping Scotland in both the UK and in Europe,# Mr Reid said. #The key issue of my campaign will be to gather support for a People’s Vote to give everyone the chance to have their say on Brexit.#The surveys we have been carrying out in Argyll and Bute show overwhelming support for a People’s Vote.#Cathy McInnes, convener of Argyll and Bute Liberal Democrats, said: #Argyll and Bute needs Alan Reid back. We want an MP with a proven track record of delivering for the constituency, not an SNP MP who will spend another five years arguing for independence.#Former councillor Andrew Nisbet who is acting at the constituency#s Liberal Democrat election agent, said: #During his  years as our local MP, Alan achieved a lot for Argyll and Bute, such as five pence a litre off fuel duty on the islands and the investment of millions of pounds to start the rollout of superfast broadband.#

title: down memory lane april 19 2019
story: It told the dramatic story of the rescue of six crewmen, from tugboat the Tynesider, after leboats, from Campbeltown and Tighnabruaich, were scrambled at am together with an air sea rescue helicopter from Prestwick.Jim McPhee, of Kintyre Hire, who was a leboat man for more than a quarter of a century, has an archive from his many years# service and a photograph from the night.The photograph which was not published in  shows the stricken tugboat Tynesider, aground, two miles south east of Tarbert  years ago.The Tynesider, on charter from Tyne and Wear Tugs, sister company to Glenlight Shipping, was on route from Troon to Ardcastle near Lochgair.She was due to uplt a barge of logs bound for Ardrossan, when she grounded on Skate Island in Lower Loch Fyne.The tug boat the Flying Childers was brought in from Greenock to assist with the rescue operation. Three attempts were made to remove the Tynesider from the island, however heavy weather pushed her further onto the rocks.Divers with portable pumps were drafted in to keep the water level down and successfully pumped out the accommodation level and down to the engine room.On Tuesday April   the anti-pollution tug, the Flying Phantom arrived from Greenock to assist the fourth attempt to pull the Tynesider off the rocks.At .am, the Tynesider, listing on her side, was successfully pulled from the rock. But within a short space of time she went down by the stern.At the time a spokesman for Glenlight said: #Divers examined underneath the tug but could find no sign of damage.#There is no pollution at the moment and it is now in the hands of insurers.#The six crew were rescued by the Campbeltown leboat and taken to Tarbert.In a complication, while the rescued men were being collected by an ambulance, a member of the leboat crew felt ill and he was taken to hospital, where it turned out he had suffered a heart attack.Mr McPhee#s Coxswain#s Certicate of Service, presented on January  , records that during his leboat service at sea  lives were saved.The Tynsider is battered and two crewmen can be seen in the sea. _crnlicert_Jim_McPhee

story: Thankfully Mark was found safe but is taking some time off to recover.What is wonderful in times of need like these is how people rally round, and it was heartening to have so many people show their concern for Mark#s wellbeing.Staff in other Courier departments and offices helped out practically and provided emotional support.Freelance reporter Joan Crooks came into the office minutes after being askedshe could lend a hand and photographer Kenny Craig stepped in at the last minute to cover weekend jobs that the Courier reporter was unable to attend, taking many of the photographs across the news and leisure pages.Former news editor Joanne Simms ed to her old beat to help with this week#s paper and her experience and connections cannot be undervalued.The Campbeltown Courier and its staff are very much part of this community and we greatly appreciated all your support.

title: stand by for another regatta
story: Kintyre Sea Sports, working  in conjunction with Dalintober Beach Group and many other local groups, will be staging Campbeltown Community Regatta again this year # after all the good work last year the  event is eagerly anticipated.The  regatta will take place on Saturday August  from am till pm and there will be opportunities for everyone to try out a iety of sea sports and beach activities.The sea sports on offer will be canoeing, dinghy sailing, kayaking, sailing in larger yachts, stand-up paddle boarding, sub-aqua ing, in the pool at Aqualibrium and wind surfingconditions permit.There will be beach games again on Dalintober Beach.A spokesperson for the regatta team said: #It is an opportunity for everyone to try out these activities and also a chance for those already proficient to join in with others having fun on the water or on the beach.#It is open to local people and visitors of all ages from five upwards, but remember that some activities will have age limits on them and will be available to those of eight-years-old or more.#And, best of all, the sports are free for all participants.There will be refreshments available at very reasonable rates on Dalintober Beach and at Campbeltown Sailing Club.More details will be revealed as the big day approaches, so keep an eye on the Courier and the Kintyre Sea Sports web page, where, closer to the event, there will be an online booking form.

title: letter scots builders buck trend
story: Scotland’s small building firms had a strong start to , in contrast to the UK construction small and medium sized enterprisesector, according to the Federation of Master BuildersScotland.The FMB State of Trade Survey for the first quarter of , the only quarterly assessment of the UK-wide SME construction sector, showed SME workloads declined for the first time in six years.In Scotland, however, there was a jump of  per cent compared with the previous quarter. Thirty per cent of weighted responses were positive, up from  per cent from the fourth quarter of .It is encouraging the Scottish construction industry is bucking the wider Brexit trend with workloads and enquires in rude health. The UK-wide picture is very dferent, with the construction SME sector overall contracting for the first time in six years.Scotland’s good fortune could be due to fewer EU workers being based north of the border compared with other parts of the country, like in London where one in three construction workers are from the EU.Relying less heavily on migrant workers has meant the Scottish construction industry hasn’t fallen foul of thousands of EU workers ing home during the long march to Brexit due to no longer feeling welcome in the UK or sure of their future here.Scotland’s builders, however, must not be complacent. Looking ahead, the First Minister has indicated thatthe UK does leave the EU later this year, she wants a second independence referendum before the next Scottish Parliament election in . This additional political uncertainty, on top of the continued uncertainty stemming from Brexit, could impact on the construction sector in Scotland.The fear is a looming second referendum could test consumer confidence this year and next. For construction SMEs, this is particularly concerning as their prospects are vulnerable to dips in consumer confidence as so much work comes from the private domestic sector.Gordon Nelson,

title: deal-reached-to-sell-part-of-former-cockenzie-power-station-site
story: However, the size of the site which has been set aside is understood to be less than a third of the land originally proposed by the company.The local authority has announced that it has signed an options agreement with Inch Cape for a ldquosmall part of the former power station site, which is understood to be about seven acres of the -acre site.It has also agreed to the land used being to
